contents.title: ECMAScript (aka ES)
contents.description: ECMAScript is a standard for scripting languages, such as JavaScript, JScript, and ActionScript. It is standardized by the Ecma International standards organization in the ECMA-262 and ECMA-402 specifications. The ECMAScript specification is a standardized specification of a scripting language developed by Brendan Eich of Netscape; initially it was named Mocha, later LiveScript, and finally JavaScript.

children.value: ECMAScript is a standard for scripting languages, such as JavaScript, JScript, and ActionScript. It is standardized by the Ecma International standards organization in the ECMA-262 and ECMA-402 specifications. The ECMAScript specification is a standardized specification of a scripting language developed by Brendan Eich of Netscape; initially it was named Mocha, later LiveScript, and finally JavaScript.

ECMAScript is a standard for scripting languages, such as JavaScript, JScript, and ActionScript. It is standardized by the Ecma International standards organization in the ECMA-262 and ECMA-402 specifications. The ECMAScript specification is a standardized specification of a scripting language developed by Brendan Eich of Netscape; initially it was named Mocha, later LiveScript, and finally JavaScript.
ECMAScript 2023 is the 14th edition of the ECMAScript standard, it was released on June, 2023 and has been implemented by major web browsers.
method is a new method that allows you to group an array of objects by a specific key.
method changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements and/or adding new elements in place, like the
method, but it returns a new array with the spliced elements.
method returns a new array with the elements sorted.
method returns a new array with the elements reversed.
method returns the last element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.
method returns the index of the last element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.
method is a new method that allows you to change the value of a given index. It returns a new array with the element at the given index replaced with the given value.
ECMAScript 2022 is the 13th edition of the ECMAScript standard, it was released on June, 2022 and has been implemented by major web browsers.
Now the await can be used at the top level of a module and can be super handy when initializing imports and creating fallbacks.
Private instance fields, methods, and accessors
With ES2022 was added as new features as private instance fields, methods, and accessors. We need to add just # at the beginning of the method name and in that way will be declared as private.
// SyntaxError: Private field '#name' must be declared in an enclosing class
// Output: TypeError: person.setName is not a function
Static class fields and methods are not used on instances of a class. Instead, can be called on the class itself and is declared using the static keyword.
This new feature provides a mechanism for additional static initialization during class definition evaluation.

Error and its subclasses now let us specify the reason behind the error. With the Error cause, we can add more intrinsic information for our errors. To use this new feature, we should specify the error options as a second parameter, and with the cause key we can pass the error that we want to chain.

props.code:
const error = new Error('Error message', { cause: new Error('Cause message') });
console.log(error.cause); // Error: Cause message

children.value: The .at() method returns the element at the specified index. If the index is negative, the element is counted from the end of the array, string, or typed array. If the index is greater than or equal to the length of the array, string, or typed array, undefined is returned.

props.code:
const array = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'];
console.log(array.at(0)); // a
console.log(array.at(-1)); // e
console.log(array.at(10)); // undefined

children.value: The .hasOwn() method returns a boolean indicating whether the object has the specified property as its own property (as opposed to inheriting it).
The new /d flag feature provides some additional information about the start and indices position end of each match in the input string.
ECMAScript 2021 is the 12th edition of the ECMAScript standard, it was released on June 15, 2021 and has been implemented by major web browsers.
ECMAScript 2021 introduces a number of new features, including:

This method allows you to replace all specified characters in a string without using a regular expression.
The method takes two parameters: the character we want to replace and the character we want to replace it with.

props.code:
const str = 'Hello World';
console.log(str.replaceAll('l', 'x')); // Hexxo Worxd

children.value: takes an array of promises as an argument. If all promises are resolved, the first one resolved will be returned. If all promises are rejected, an
The numeric separators make it easy to read large numbers within our code by adding the

props.code:
const number = 1_000_000;
console.log(number); // 1000000

children.value: The key restriction to keep in mind is: you can only enter

characters between two digits.
Another very important aspect to keep in mind is that it is not possible to parse numbers that use separators.

A WeakRef object contains a weak reference to an object named target or referent. A weak reference to an object is a reference that does not prevent the object from being reclaimed by the garbage collector. Conversely, a normal (or strong) reference keeps an object in memory. When an object no longer has strong references to it, the JavaScript engine's garbage collector can destroy the object and reclaim its memory. In that case, it is no longer possible to get the object from a weak reference.
The main use of weak references (WeakRef) is to implement caches on large objects.
Three new logical assignment operators have been introduced namely: &&=, ||=, and ??=.
The first operator, &&=, is used between two values. If the first value is true, the second value will be assigned to the first.
The second operator, i.e. ||=, is also used between two values, with the difference however that, in this case, if the first value is not true, then the second value will be assigned to the first.
Finally the third operator ??=. This operator checks if the first value is null or undefined. If it is, then the second value is assigned to the first.
ECMAScript 2020 is the twelfth edition of the ECMAScript language specification, it was released on June 15, 2020 and has been implemented by major web browsers.
ECMAScript 2020 introduces a number of new features, including:
is a built-in object that provides a way to represent whole numbers larger than 2  1, which is the largest number in JS.
returns a promise for the module namespace object of the requested module. Therefore, imports can now be assigned to a variable using async/await.

props.code: const module = await import('./module.js');

Class fields are public by default, but private class members can be created by using a hash
Like public fields, private fields are added at construction time in a base class, or at the point where super() is invoked in a subclass.
Private static fields are added to the class constructor at class evaluation time.
Private instance methods are methods available on class instances whose access is restricted in the same manner as private instance fields.
method creates a new array with all sub-array elements concatenated into it recursively up to the specified depth.

props.code:
let array1 = ['a', 'b', [1, 2, 3]];
console.log(array1.flat()); // ['a', 'b', 1, 2, 3]

children.value: The method excludes gaps or empty elements in the array.
method returns a new array formed by applying a given callback function to each element of the array, and then flattening the result by one level. It is identical to a
of depth 1, but slightly more efficient than calling those two methods separately.

props.code:
let array1 = [1, 2, 3, 4];
console.log(array1.flatMap((x) => [x + 1])); // [2, 3, 4, 5]

children.value: method transforms a list of key-value pairs into an object.
) removes whitespace from the beginning of a string.
) removes whitespace from the end of a string.
It is now possible to use the
block without having to supply the error parameter inside the catch block.
// no binding or parameter to handle it
property has been added to retrieve the description from a symbol.

props.code:
const symbol1 = Symbol('my symbol');
console.log(symbol1.description); // 'my symbol'

The rest operator puts the rest of some specific user-supplied values into a JavaScript array.
The spread operator can be used to combine multiple objects or cloning objects.

contents.title: Clean code in Node.js
contents.description: Clean code is an important aspect of software development, as it makes the code more readable, maintainable, and scalable.

children.value: Clean code is an important aspect of software development, as it makes the code more readable, maintainable, and scalable.
Clean code is an important aspect of software development, as it makes the code more readable, maintainable, and scalable.
: Each layer of the application should have a single responsibility
: High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Instead, both should depend on abstractions
: The code should be designed in a way that makes it easy to write automated tests
use intention-revealing names and dont worry if you have long variable names
make meaningful distinctions and dont add extra, unnecessary nouns to the variable names
make your variable names easy to pronounce
a function should do one thing only on one level of abstraction
use long, descriptive names, a function name should be a verb or a verb phrase, and it needs to communicate its intent, as well as the order and intent of the arguments
avoid long argument list, use a single object parameter and destructuring assignment instead
use pure functions and reduce side effects
organize your functions in a file according to the stepdown rule, higher level functions should be on top and lower levels below. It makes it natural to read the source code
functions should either do something (modify) or answer something (query), but not both
use promises or async/await instead of callbacks for asynchronous operations
use comments to explain complex code or to provide context
use error handling to gracefully handle errors and avoid crashing the application
use a consistent coding style and formatting
To implement Clean Architecture in Node.js, the application can be divided into layers, with each layer having a specific responsibility following these steps:
define the layers of the application
define the interfaces between the layers
implement the layers, starting from the innermost layer and working outwards
use dependency injection to ensure that each layer depends only on abstractions, not on concrete implementations
For example, the application can be divided into the following layers:
Presentation layer: Handles user input and output
Application layer: Contains the business logic of the application
Routes: register routes and redirect incoming request to its respective controller
Controller: handle incoming request, validate request body and send response to client
Database: encapsulate all DB queries and expose it with a single interface
Domain layer: Contains the core business logic and entities of the application
Infrastructure layer: Contains the implementation details of the application, such as the database and external APIs
By separating the application into layers, each layer can be tested independently, and changes to one layer do not affect the other layers.

contents.title: URL shortener with Node.js, Express and MongoDB
contents.description: Learn how to build a URL shortener using Node.js, Express, and MongoDB with this step-by-step technical article. Explore the process of generating short URLs, handling redirects, and storing data in MongoDB. Gain practical knowledge to create your own custom URL shortening service efficiently.

contents.title: Structural Pattern Design - Adapter
contents.description: Discover the power of the Adapter design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Learn how to seamlessly integrate incompatible interfaces, adapt third-party libraries, and improve code maintainability. Explore practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Adapter pattern effectively in your Node.js applications.

children.value: Discover the power of the Adapter design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Learn how to seamlessly integrate incompatible interfaces, adapt third-party libraries, and improve code maintainability. Explore practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Adapter pattern effectively in your Node.js applications.

Discover the power of the Adapter design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Learn how to seamlessly integrate incompatible interfaces, adapt third-party libraries, and improve code maintainability. Explore practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Adapter pattern effectively in your Node.js applications.
To implement this pattern it is sufficient to create an adapter that wraps the incompatible object and make it capable of "communicating" with the other object.
For example, let's say in a project you use Redis to read and write data and you want to switch to Mongo instead.

The classes of the two clients have different interfaces and in order to migrate to Mongo use there are two solutions: rewrite the code in which the "incompatible" functions are called or create an adapter.

contents.title: Structural Design Pattern - Bridge
contents.description: Unleash the flexibility of the Bridge design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to decouple abstraction from implementation, manage complex hierarchies, and enable future scalability. Learn practical techniques and examples to apply the Bridge pattern effectively in your Node.js projects, enhancing code organization and extensibility.

children.value: Unleash the flexibility of the Bridge design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to decouple abstraction from implementation, manage complex hierarchies, and enable future scalability. Learn practical techniques and examples to apply the Bridge pattern effectively in your Node.js projects, enhancing code organization and extensibility.

Unleash the flexibility of the Bridge design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to decouple abstraction from implementation, manage complex hierarchies, and enable future scalability. Learn practical techniques and examples to apply the Bridge pattern effectively in your Node.js projects, enhancing code organization and extensibility.
This pattern allows implementations to change independently of the classes that use them, making the code more flexible and modular.

The Bridge pattern consists of two parts: the interface and the implementation. Interface is an abstraction that defines the functionality an implementation must provide. The implementation is the concrete class that actually provides the functionality.

The main advantage of the Bridge pattern is that it separates the responsibility of providing functionality from that of providing implementation. This means that the classes using the interface are not dependent on specific implementing classes. This makes your code more flexible and modular, because changes to implementations don't affect the classes that use them.

An example of using the Bridge pattern can be seen in an application that uses several databases. The interface can define common functionality such as inserting, updating and deleting data, while specific implementation classes can provide implementations for individual databases such as MySQL or PostgreSQL.
In general, the Bridge pattern is useful when you want to create a flexible architecture, where business logic is separated from its concrete implementations, avoiding creating monolithic classes.

To implement the Bridge pattern in JavaScript, you can use a combination of classes and constructor functions (constructors). The interface class can define a common interface to the object that will be used by the other classes, while the implementation classes will provide the actual implementation of the functionality.

A practical example would be a "Renderer" class as an interface, with two implementation classes: "CanvasRenderer" and "SVGRenderer", both of which extend the "Renderer" class and provide a specific rendering method implementation. This way, any class that needs rendering can use this interface and doesn't depend on a specific implementation.
Renderer is an abstract class and cannot be instantiated.
This method must be implemented by a subclass.
// The Circle class uses the renderer interface to render
// Output: "Rendering circle with radius 10 on canvas"
// Output: "Rendering circle with radius 10 on SVG"

In this example, the Circle class uses the Renderer interface to render the circle. This way the circle object doesn't depend on a specific renderer implementation, but only on the interface. It is possible to change the implementation using the renderer by simply changing the assigned renderer object.

It is also possible to use functional programming and closures to implement the Bridge pattern in JavaScript, exploiting the flexibility of the language and the possibility of creating "factory" functions to generate interfaces and their implementations.

contents.title: Structural Design Pattern - Composite
contents.description: Uncover the potential of the Composite design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to create tree-like structures, treat individual objects and groups uniformly, and simplify complex operations. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to harness the power of the Composite pattern in your Node.js applications.

children.value: Uncover the potential of the Composite design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to create tree-like structures, treat individual objects and groups uniformly, and simplify complex operations. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to harness the power of the Composite pattern in your Node.js applications.

Uncover the potential of the Composite design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to create tree-like structures, treat individual objects and groups uniformly, and simplify complex operations. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to harness the power of the Composite pattern in your Node.js applications.

Questo pattern consente di trattare oggetti singoli e raggruppamenti di oggetti allo stesso modo, in modo da poter trattare i componenti di una struttura in modo uniforme, indipendentemente dal loro livello di gerarchia.

Il pattern Composite  composto da due tipi di classi: la classe base "Component" e la classe derivata "Composite". La classe base rappresenta i singoli elementi della struttura ad albero, mentre la classe Composite rappresenta gli elementi composti che possono contenere altri elementi.

La classe Composite implementa i metodi base della classe Componente, ma in aggiunta, essa include anche metodi per aggiungere, rimuovere o accedere ai suoi elementi figlio. Ci consente di creare strutture ad albero anche gerarchiche complesse, che sono comunque gestibili tramite un'interfaccia comune.
Inoltre, l'utilizzo di questo pattern permette di creare una relazione tra gli oggetti, che pu essere utilizzata per esempio, per la navigazione della struttura ad albero.

Un esempio comune di utilizzo del pattern Composite  la creazione di un file system. In un file system, ci sono cartelle e file. Le cartelle possono contenere altre cartelle o file, mentre i file non possono contenere altri elementi. Utilizzando il pattern Composite,  possibile creare una classe "Cartella" che rappresenta sia le cartelle principali che le sottocartelle, e una classe "File" che rappresenta i file. Entrambe le classi estendono un'interfaccia comune chiamata "Component", che definisce i metodi comuni a entrambe le classi.

Per la creazione di questo pattern in javascript,  possibile utilizzare le propriet dell'oggetto e dell'ereditariet presenti nella programmazione orientata agli oggetti in javascript (es: classi, ereditariet tramite prototipi) per creare la classe base "Component" e la classe derivata "Composite", e metodi per gestire la gerarchia degli elementi.
Renderer is an abstract class and cannot be instantiated.
This method must be implemented by a subclass.
// The Circle class uses the renderer interface to render
// Output: "Rendering circle with radius 10 on canvas"
// Output: "Rendering circle with radius 10 on SVG"

In this example, the Circle class uses the Renderer interface to render the circle. This way the circle object doesn't depend on a specific renderer implementation, but only on the interface. It is possible to change the implementation using the renderer by simply changing the assigned renderer object.

It is also possible to use functional programming and closures to implement the Bridge pattern in JavaScript, exploiting the flexibility of the language and the possibility of creating "factory" functions to generate interfaces and their implementations.

contents.title: Structural Pattern Design - Decorator
contents.description: Discover the versatility of the Decorator design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to dynamically add functionality to objects, without modifying their original structure. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Decorator pattern in your Node.js applications, enhancing code reusability and flexibility.

children.value: Discover the versatility of the Decorator design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to dynamically add functionality to objects, without modifying their original structure. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Decorator pattern in your Node.js applications, enhancing code reusability and flexibility.

Discover the versatility of the Decorator design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to dynamically add functionality to objects, without modifying their original structure. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Decorator pattern in your Node.js applications, enhancing code reusability and flexibility.

The pattern is similar to the classic inheritance but unlike the latter the new features are not added to all objects of the same class but only to those instances that have been explicitly "decorated".
To implement this pattern it is sufficient to create a "decorator" function which receives an object as input and returns the "decorated" version.

contents.title: Creational design patterns - Factory
contents.description: Explore the Factory design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Learn how to encapsulate object creation, abstract the creation process, and enhance code flexibility. Discover practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Factory pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient and scalable object creation.

children.value: Explore the Factory design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Learn how to encapsulate object creation, abstract the creation process, and enhance code flexibility. Discover practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Factory pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient and scalable object creation.

Explore the Factory design pattern in Node.js with this insightful article. Learn how to encapsulate object creation, abstract the creation process, and enhance code flexibility. Discover practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Factory pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient and scalable object creation.

The advantage of this approach consists in letting the factory decide how to instantiate the object (using closures, prototype, the new operator or other), thus not binding the creation to a specific technique and guaranteeing greater flexibility. (especially useful in the refactor phase).
Obviously the modalities (constructors / methods) with which the factory will create the various objects should not be directly accessible by the "consumers" - to avoid that they can be modified.
// Hi, I'm a full time employee
// Hi, I'm a part time employee

contents.title: Structural Design Pattern - Proxy
contents.description: Unleash the power of the Proxy design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Discover how to control access to objects, add additional functionality, and implement caching and logging mechanisms. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Proxy pattern in your Node.js applications for enhanced security and performance.

Discover how to control access to objects, add additional functionality, and implement caching and logging mechanisms. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Proxy pattern in your Node.js applications for enhanced security and performance.

Unleash the power of the Proxy design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Discover how to control access to objects, add additional functionality, and implement caching and logging mechanisms. Learn practical examples and implementation techniques to leverage the Proxy pattern in your Node.js applications for enhanced security and performance.

The proxy and the original object, defined as "subject", have the same interface and this therefore allows them to exchange transparently with each other. The proxy, as mentioned, intercepts all or only some operations that are intended to be performed on the subject, modifying or enriching their behavior.
There are various ways to implement this pattern, for example through "Composition" or using the Proxy API.

With the "composition" technique, one object is combined with another to extend or use its functionality. In the case of the proxy, the new object has the same interface as the subject from which it was created and maintains an internal reference to the original object in the form of an instance variable. Inside the proxy you will need to intercept the methods you want to manipulate and delegate the rest to the original object.
Using these APIs allows you to have an object proxy passed as a parameter.

props.code: const p = new Proxy(target, handler);

children.value: is the original object and the
is an object that defines which operations will be intercepted and how they will be handled.

contents.title: Creational Design Patterns - Singleton
contents.description: Unlock the potential of the Singleton design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to ensure a single instance of a class, share resources, and maintain global state. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Singleton pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient resource management.

children.value: Unlock the potential of the Singleton design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to ensure a single instance of a class, share resources, and maintain global state. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Singleton pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient resource management.

Unlock the potential of the Singleton design pattern in Node.js with this informative article. Explore how to ensure a single instance of a class, share resources, and maintain global state. Learn practical examples and implementation strategies to leverage the Singleton pattern in your Node.js applications for efficient resource management.
In general, two main operations are required to implement this pattern:
make the constructor of the class private, which prevents multiple objects from being instantiated.

declare a public (static) method that allows you to retrieve the instance. This method will only call the private constructor, to create the object, and save it in a static field on the first call and return the same object on subsequent calls.
In JS we can save the instance in a local variable and, instead of defining the
class, we can use the method
to pre-govern changes and finally implement the "lazy" initialization inside the constructor.
At this point we can call the class like this:
A possible alternative is to take advantage of the
which allows you to keep the modules that are loaded in the cache and call the same object every time the same file is fixed. The singleton code would then be reduced to:

props.code:
const Singleton = require('./Singleton');
const instance = Singleton;

children.value: The only note to keep in mind is that since Node.js is case-sensitive, resolving modules with different file names will produce different instances.

contents.title: Random number generator with Node.js
contents.description: Learn how to create a Random Number Generator in Node.js with this practical article. Explore different methods and libraries available, from generating random integers to floating-point numbers. Gain insights into ensuring randomness and security, and implement the RNG functionality in your Node.js applications effectively.

children.value: Learn how to create a Random Number Generator in Node.js with this practical article. Explore different methods and libraries available, from generating random integers to floating-point numbers. Gain insights into ensuring randomness and security, and implement the RNG functionality in your Node.js applications effectively.

Learn how to create a Random Number Generator in Node.js with this practical article. Explore different methods and libraries available, from generating random integers to floating-point numbers. Gain insights into ensuring randomness and security, and implement the RNG functionality in your Node.js applications effectively.
In general, there are three types of "random":
: that is the randomness to which no model or algorithm is applied (but whose existence is questionable)
:, not exactly random but definitely impossible to predict
: what most people think of when they think of the "random" number

"Irregular" numbers are quick to generate, but absolutely useless for security purposes: even if there doesn't seem to be a pattern, there is almost always a way to predict their values. The only realistic use case for irregular values is things that are represented visually, such as game elements or randomly generated sentences.

The "unpredictable" numbers are a little slower to generate but more resistant to attacks. This data is provided by what is called the Cryptographically Secure Pseudo-Random Number Generator (CSPRNG).

method is often used which however is not a true random number generator but is pseudo-random, this is because over time the numbers begin to repeat themselves and eventually show a non-random pattern, thus re-entering among the "irregular" generators. A possible alternative comes from the use of the

The Web Crypto API are used to perform cryptographic operations (such as hashing, signature generation and verification, encryption and decryption) but among the various methods, the one that interests our case is the

method which provides numbers random. The method accepts as a parameter the number of bytes to generate and returns a Buffer. Node.js provides an implementation of the standard through the use of the framework's native
The random bytes of data generated is:
However, although the method is a CSPRNG it is not recommended to use it directly because it is easy to alter the result when it is "transformed".
Two solutions are therefore suggested in Node.js:
if you need to generate single random numbers in a certain range it is recommended to use the form
if you need to generate API keys or tokens of some kind better use
Both use a CSPRNG but "transform" the bytes impartially and therefore safely.

contents.title: Node.js serverless
contents.description: Unleash the potential of the Serverless Framework in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to build, deploy, and manage serverless applications effortlessly. Learn about the framework's key features, deployment options, and integration with popular cloud providers. Streamline your development workflow and harness the power of serverless architecture in Node.js.

children.value: Unleash the potential of the Serverless Framework in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to build, deploy, and manage serverless applications effortlessly. Learn about the framework's key features, deployment options, and integration with popular cloud providers. Streamline your development workflow and harness the power of serverless architecture in Node.js.

Unleash the potential of the Serverless Framework in Node.js with this insightful article. Explore how to build, deploy, and manage serverless applications effortlessly. Learn about the framework's key features, deployment options, and integration with popular cloud providers. Streamline your development workflow and harness the power of serverless architecture in Node.js.
In this example we will use the
, a multiprovider framework that simplifies the construction and deployment process, and in particular we will use the [Lambda](https: // aws. amazon.com/lambda) service from AWS.
We obviously start by installing the CLI

props.code: npm install serverless -g

children.value: and then in a folder of our liking we start the application's boilerplate using the command

props.code: serverless create -t aws-nodejs

children.value: which will initialize the folder with:
containing the configuration that the framework uses to create the service. The file has three sections:
: in which all the functions of which the service is composed are specified
: where all the resources used by the functions are listed
contains the function that will be deployed
In general, the handler is composed of a stateless function of the type
represents the type of event that triggered the function
contains information about the environment on which the function will run
is the function that takes care of returning a response or an error based on the request received
After implementing all the logic of our application we will need to record everything inside the

props.code:
service: my-application

provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: nodejs14.17.4
  stage: dev
  region: us-east-1

functions:
  app:
    handler: index.handler
    events:
      - http: ...

children.value: At this point it is possible to release everything using the command

props.code: sls deploy -v

children.value: or by implementing an npm command
To speed up the release if only one function is modified, the command can be used

props.code: sls deploy function -f myFuncName

children.value: which is much faster than the simple
To remotely debug the code, you can tap into the application logs using the command

props.code: serverless logs -f myFuncName -t

children.value: To test the code locally, you can use a plugin (
) that allows you to emulate Lambda and API Gateway services offline. Just add the dependency to the project (under development dependencies) and add it to the
To start everything, the command will suffice

props.code: sls offline

contents.title: Node.js Stream
contents.description: Dive into the world of Node.js Streams with this comprehensive article. Explore the power and versatility of streams for efficient data processing, I/O operations, and building scalable applications. Learn about different types of streams, data transformation, and best practices to leverage the full potential of Node.js Streams.

children.value: Dive into the world of Node.js Streams with this comprehensive article. Explore the power and versatility of streams for efficient data processing, I/O operations, and building scalable applications. Learn about different types of streams, data transformation, and best practices to leverage the full potential of Node.js Streams.

Dive into the world of Node.js Streams with this comprehensive article. Explore the power and versatility of streams for efficient data processing, I/O operations, and building scalable applications. Learn about different types of streams, data transformation, and best practices to leverage the full potential of Node.js Streams.
One of the reasons why they are one of the most appreciated features of Node is the possibility they give to work with large amounts of data in environments with limited resources.
The Streams are contained in the
which is part of the core of the framework and are divided into four categories:
, to read data, transform them and then write them
and emit different types of events. Among these are:
- emitted when new data is" read "from the stream.
- issued when there is no more data available in the stream and all available data has already been" read "
- emitted when a write stream is finished and all writes have completed.
- issued when a stream is completely closed. Unlike
this event is not guaranteed to be emitted.
- issued when a stream encounters some error. It is usually (but not always) followed by the
- emitted when a reading stream is paused.
- emitted when a read stream is taken out of pause.
To connect various streams together, and therefore have a more complex management of the data flow, we can use the
method. The method will do nothing but listen for the
event of the starting stream (the stream on which the method is invoked) which will write the data to the destination stream (the one passed as a parameter to the method).

props.code: source.pipe(destination);

children.value: Obviously such an operation could be done easily manually without using the method but using pipe is much safer because the so-called
is managed automatically, a technique used in cases where the data reading process is very faster than writing.
Normally the writing stream is automatically closed when there is no more data to "read", if instead we need to keep it still open just add a parameter

props.code: source.pipe(destination, { end: false });

children.value: One of the weaknesses of the method is the absence of error handling. In fact, if one of the streams involved fails the "pipeline" would be interrupted and it will be up to us to try to understand where the problem is and destroy the remaining streams to avoid a memory leak.
An alternative solution is given by the external module (pump)
. The method provided by the module will handle streams errors internally, listening for the
events, and take care of destroying the remaining streams.

props.code:
const pump = require('pump');

pump(stream1, stream2, stream3, ...);

children.value: This type of stream comes in handy when we want to create a stream of data that other users can "read" (for example a stream that reads data from a file saved on disk).
There are two ways to extract data from the stream: "pulling mode" and "pushing mode".
In "pull" mode it is sufficient to listen for the
event which will be called every time a new piece of data is read.

props.code: myStream.on('data', handlerFunction);

children.value: To stop the incoming data stream, you can pause it, using the
method, and then resume it by calling the

props.code:
myStream.pause();
myStream.resume();

children.value: This mode involves problems because if the stream is excessively "loaded" with incoming data, it risks not respecting the pause state.
In "push" mode to extract the data just wait until the stream is in a
(which represents the end of the stream). In this mode, to stop the data flow it will be enough to stop requesting data from the stream.
This type of stream comes in handy when we want to create a stream that can allow other users to "write" data (for example a stream to write data to a file saved on disk).

This third type of stream is a mixed version that collects the two functionalities of the two previous streams, read and write (for example a gzip stream that compresses the data that is passed to it in input).
is a type of Duplex stream that acts as a tunnel to convey the read stream to a writable stream. Through the tunnel it is possible to check the processed data.
This last type of stream allows you to "transform" the data "written" on the stream and make it available for "reading" at the stream output.
For example, let's create a stream that reads the entered text, capitalizes it and reprints it on the screen
If our stream does not return serializable data (a Buffer or a string) it is necessary to use the

. In this mode simply the returned values are generic objects and the only difference is the amount of data buffered. When this default mode is not used, the stream will use a buffer of 16kb of data before pausing, while in the active mode the stream will stop when it has buffered 16 objects.

experiences.title: Node.js back-end developer
experiences.description:
Artshell is a software for the complete management of collections of works of art, designed for gallery owners, collectors and artists.

As a back-end developer I take care of the maintenance, design and implementation of the new API functionalities of the application and of the releases on the cloud platform.

Technologies and tools used: NodeJS, Express, GraphQL, Elasticsearch, AWS Visual Studio Code, Git, npm, Docker.

experiences.title: Full-stack developer
experiences.description:
SAEP ICT Engineering is a consulting and development company for WEB, Mobile and IoT applications.

As a full-stack developer I have participated in several projects:
  • web + mobile application: Symfony + MySQL + Apache CouchDB + Android
  • mobile application: Android
  • web application: Spring Boot REST + MySQL + Redis
  • web application: Spring Boot REST + Vaadin + PostgreSQL + Elasticsearch
  • web application: Django + PostgreSQL + CouchBase

Other technologies and tools used: IntelliJ IDEA, Android Studio, Git, Docker, Amazon AWS, Jenkins, Visual Studio Code, Pycharm.

experiences.title: Java EE developer
experiences.description:
Reply is a consulting company specializing in the design, implementation and maintenance of Internet and social network based solutions.

As a Java programmer I dealt with the development of the evolution and the maintenance of a back office portal in the banking sector, both front-end and back-end side, the maintenance of ETLs for loading flows and the Web Service used for interaction with other suppliers.

Technologies and tools used: Java EE, EJB3, JSF, XHTML, CSS, SQL (Oracle), SVN.

experiences.title: Java EE/COBOL developer
experiences.description:
Sydema is a software house of IT products able to support the business of the banking sector.

As a Java developer I have been involved in the development of the evolution and maintenance of the software for credit management installed at the customer.

Technologies and tools used: Java EE, JSP, AJAX, Javascript, HTML, CSS, SQL (DB2), COBOL, Tomcat, SVN.
